text: chatham is a historically safe
middle-class Enclave on Chicago's
turbulent south side but in 2010 as the
recession deepened it appeared to be on
the verge of losing its identity we were
blindsided by the actual event not in a
million years would I have thought that
that thing would happen at cole park a
crowd gathered last night to remember
officer thomas wertham the fourth he was
shot and killed not far from there on
Wednesday night wortham was showing his
parents the new motorcycle he bought
after safely returning from a second
tour of duty in Iraq he went to war and
lived and then he dies in front of our
house I always tell people we were never
like a perfect family oh my god like I
argue with Thomas for like the last 15
years of my life we didn't talk everyday
we weren't like best friends but I think
for me it was always the four of us like
no matter what there were four people in
this family and now it's the three of us
a lot of people who I'll meet in the
grocery store so I played at that park
so it violated their sense of home when
he can get murdered in front of his home
who's safe who anywhere is safe
you
checking was a place 20 years ago when
we moved in you couldn't find out vacant
house in channel that was one of the
most saw that the hardest place to move
in in the city of Chicago there was no
crime in chatham 20 years ago to speak
of growing up here was like sort of like
growing up in a small town the kind of
place where people stayed in the same
house for generations there was a sense
of legacy if you were misbehaving in any
way or if you stepped on someone's lawn
by the time you got home your parents
already knew because someone had
corrected you on the way and then called
your mom and dad I had really wanted to
come back here with my kids because I
wanted them to have the same quality of
life that I had to have survived two
tours in Iraq but not be able to survive
the streets of the south side of Chicago
to me I find an unacceptable
the wortham is debated whether it was
time to leave behind the community they
helped build well that would be the
simple solution is to move just pack up
and leave but we have to teach people
the community everybody you can't have
long you gotta treat people the way you
want to be treated the neighborhood is
surrounded on all sides by pockets of
poverty that have become even more
desperate during the recession but
Chatham's history of collective action
and it's shared ethics may be the key to
its survival
I mean every day somebody's been shot
and I think this is where we can step in
and we can change the person's values
about life people who bear your life
don't go out and kill people I try and
celebrate his life by talking about the
good things that he did and how he never
quit Tommy would not have wanted this to
happen to him but he would be upset with
us if something good didn't come out of
it
you
